titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. Monday.

The biennial election day for Mayor, Aldermen and common Councilmen of the City of Washington— William W. Seaton was elected Mayor in the place of Peter Force, who has held the office four years.— I called this morning at the City Hall upon Mr Andrew Rothwell Treasurer of the Columbian College, to ask for payment of the years interest on their bond to me, this day payable. He said he had money; but was so much engaged in the city election that he could not attend to me this day; and I told him I would call again to-morrow.— At the House it was the day for offering regulations. But as soon as the Journal was read, C. Cushing rose to a priviledged Question, and before he could state what it was, Waddy Thompson, acting chairman of the Military Committee moved a suspension of the rules, to take up a Bill for raising 1600 men for the defence of Florida: and he sent to the Clerk’s table a very urgent Letter from the Secretary of War, and Advices from Florida of recent massacres by the Indians of our troops.— Downing, the delegate from the Territory, added his supplicating voice to that of Genl. Thompson; but the democracy would not hear a word of it— The motion to suspend the rules was lost 118 to 94— Thompson then moved the suspension of the rules for this day—lost. 116 to 85— Hunt moved a suspension for two hours—lost 111 to 98. Triplet moved a suspension of the rules to introduce his supplementary pre-emption bill. lost—72 to 121. Cushing finally moved his privileged question which was the reconsideration of the vote of Saturday, accepting Hillen’s report from the Committee of Commerce, which a majority of that Committee had reconsidered, and reversed— Cushing’s reason for moving the re-consideration was that he had found by the yeas and nays that it was a party vote— Clifford moved the previous question Grinnell, a call of the House— Proffit to lay the whole subject on the table—on each of which questions the yeas and nays were taken. The call of the house was refused—the motion to lay on the table rejected—the previous question carried; and the reconsideration refused 84 to 108. And now came the recess— I rode home, dined and returned to the house— At 5 minutes past 4 there were more than 200 members present and debating Atherton’s motion, now offered by Albert Smith— After a confused and riotous sitting this Resolution was carried and the reconsideration of it rejected— During the whole day, I was a silent, passive, humiliated, indignant, helpless, Spectator of the Scene.— I came home after voting for the last motion of reconsideration and while they were taking the yeas and nays— We had a small Evening party. Thomas B. Frothingham came in, just from Boston— High Summer heat.
2. V. Tuesday.

Mr Vattemare was here this morning with what he called a Runic Manuscript—consisting of about half a dozen slips of old pine wood, or cedar, 4 or 5 inches long 3 inches wide and half an inch thick, slung together by twine through gimblet holes at their sides, ruled with lines like those of written music, and traversed with fantastic pot hooks and trammels, seemingly traced by a sharp ten-penny nail, and which Mr Vattemare assured me were perfectly identical with the figures on the Dighton rock— The resemblance appears to me imaginary. He thinks his manuscript at least 600 years old— He said he wished to give it to some Scientific public institution in this country, and asked my advice where to locate his treasure. I advised him to the American Philosophical Society at Philadelphia— At the House to which Mr Saltonstall rode with me. Waddy Thompson made another attempt to get up his army Bill of 1600 men to fight and be cut off the Indians in Florida; but he could not succeed— The morning hour was consumed in receiving a few reports from Committees, and postponing the motion to recommit the report of the Committee of Commerce on the Pilot Bill; and upon a snarl about an expected report for seven marine hospitals to be erected in the West, and a scuffle between Pittsburg and Wheeling for the location of one of these hospitals— The orders of the day arrested this discussion.— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Linn Banks in the Chair— The sub-treasury Bill, and a two hours speech of Isaac Leet in its favour.— At the meeting of the House there were upwards of 200 members present; but as soon as Leet began, they began to evacuate the Hall—and in ten minutes there were about 50 members left to hear him— When he finished John H. Brockway, of Connecticut took the floor, and ten minutes after came the recess— I rode home and dined— Thomas B. Frothingham dined with us— He is to leave the city upon his return homeward to-morrow— At 4 P.M— Mr. Saltonstall returned with me to the house—we found Brockway still speaking, and he continued till half past 5— Ira A. Eastman of New Hampshire followed in a panegyric upon the Bill, and an invective upon Banks; and especially the Banks of the United States, and General Harrison— It was 7 O’Clock— Osborne of Connecticut took the floor— The Committee rose—the house adjourned and I rode home alone— Mr Richard Cutts was here this Evening. I was greeted in my seat by Jabez W. Huntington, an old acquaintance, heretofore a member of the house from Connecticut, removed by an appointment as a judge of the Supreme Court of that State, and now returned by its Legislature as one of their members in the Senate of the United States— He takes the place of Mr. Betts lately deceased.
3. V. Wednesday.

On my way to the House this morning I called at the City Hall where Mr Andrew Rothwell Treasurer of the Columbian College, paid me by a check on the Bank of Washington for 2949 dollars, four years of intest on the debt due to me by that College— The debt upon their bond to me of June 1829. is 11410 dollars 74 cents—the interest upon which is 684 dollars 65 cents a year— Their last payment of interest to me, was in June 1836 on the 1st. of June 1838. their then Treasurer George Wood, gave me instead of two years interest then due a Note upon interest for 1369 dollars 38 cents and on the 1st. of June 1839. their present Treasurer Rothwell gave me a note for 766:80. instead of the interest then due— He now took up both these notes, and paid the interest now due on the principal sum.

row.cell: Interest one year to 1. June 1840. on 11410:74
Paid me, by Check on the Bank of Washington— A. Rothwell.

div.p: I enquired if they made no allowance of discount for payment in depreciated Bank Bills: he said they had made none in any of their payments heretofore— I told him that having made heretofore more than one sacrifice to favour the institution I would receive this payment and forbear to insist upon the discount— But I gave him notice and desired him to notify the board of Trustees that I should require payment of the principal in specie or its equivalent, which he said he would At the House, the Speaker had decided that the Tennessee land Bill must go to a Committee of the whole house—from which decision Horace Everett appealed— The decision was sustained by Tellers 94. negatives not counted.— Motion to commit yeas and nays 104 to 65. No sooner was the vote taken than Hubbard of Alabama moved a reconsideration, and made a Speech.— Howard of Indiana gave notice that he would move to morrow the reconsideration of the decision that the Bill must go to a Committee of the whole— Lewis Williams moved the previous question upon Hubbard’s motion to reconsider. Yeas and nays 82 to 90. And thus was the morning hour consumed. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Linn Banks in the Chair.— Thomas H. Osborne of Connecticut made a very modest, sensible Speech against the Bill, of an hour and a half—followed by Hiram P. Hunt of New-York on the same side— He spoke till the recess and as I concluded he would occupy the remainder of the day, I rode home and did not return to the house after dinner— Mary wrote for me—to make up the report of my speeches on the 9th. instt. Mr Vattemare was here this Evening, and explained to the Ladies the engravings and fac-similies of Autographs in his Album Cosmopolite. Mrs Thornton, Mrs Talbot and her daughter Mary were also here.
4. V. Thursday.

Meeting of the Committee of manufactures. Present Adams, Davis, Eastman, Slade, Dromgoole, who was also attending in the adjoining chamber of the Committee of Foreign Affairs, waiting for a Quorum there.— He came in at last, to make a Quorum for us, but only a few minutes before the meeting of the House; so that the Committee could do nothing but postpone all the business last referred to them by the house, which since the 1st. of last Month has been considerable— In the house Petrikin offered a Resolution of enquiry how many superintendants, assistant superintendants, foremen, bosses, and workman are employed, on the Treasury and Patent Office buildings and their respective wages—which was adopted. Curtis occupied the morning hour with a speech for the recommitment of Hillen’s bill to repeal the pilot Law— Hoffman attempted to get up the Bill authorising the Secretary of the Treasury to compound with the sureties of Samuel Swartwout—and Sergeant offered a report of the Committee on the judiciary— But Atherton insisted on the order of the day— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union; Linn Banks in the Chair, and the subtreasury Bill.— Henry Williams of Taunton who represents the 10th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, made a speech of nearly two hours for the Bill and against the Banks. He is a young man, of modest deportment, and very intelligent, rather effeminate countenance— He has been hitherto a mute administration voter— His Speech this day disclosed no lack either of assurance or of fluency— But it was so insupportably destitute of original thought, and so redundant of commonplace party slang, that after wearing out my patience for an hour, it fairly drove me from the Hall, and I went into the Senate chamber.— There I heard the close of a Speech of Henry Clay, and the beginning of one of Silas Wright upon the Bankrupt bill, now before that body.— When I returned to the house, the recess had commenced. Henry Williams had finished his Speech, and John Smith of Vermont had begun another like unto it. I rode home, dined and returned to the house at 4. P.M—taking back Mr Vattemare’s Album cosmopolite— I found John Smith, hammering away for the independent Treasury, and against the Banks— He finished soon after 5—and Anson Brown of New-York, followed for an hour against the Bill— John White of Kentucky then took the floor, the Committee rose, the house adjourned and I walked home— Mr Fendall spent an hour of the Evening with me— I finished for Charles Ogle, the ballad on the wants of man, in 23. Stanzas.— I had given a copy of one of them (the wife) to John Bell for a Mrs Morehead of Ohio, who had requested an autograph signature— William C. Dawson this day requested of me some lines in my own handwriting to send to Mrs Dawson— Do I waste too much time upon these trifles? What better can I do?
5. V. Friday

Morning visit from Mr Raymond, formerly of Baltimore, but now as he informed me settled in Allegany County Maryland— He was the author of a book upon political economy, once in some repute; but he appears not to take much interest in the subject now— I called at the Treasury Department at the Office of the first Auditor Jesse D. Miller, with a Treasury Note for 1000 dollars which should have been paid the 17th. of last Month; but which the disability of my arm, and other avocations have delayed. I enquired at what rate of interest Treasury Notes were issued now— He did not know— I left the note with him stating my willingness either to receive payment here or to have it renewed at the same rate of interest, which it bore, 6 percent, for another year. I found the house in Session; and Mr Chinn offering again a Resolution which the house had refused to receive, calling on the Postmaster General for a report concerning a defaulting Postmaster, at Baton rouge Louisiana; M’Kay now moved a suspension of the rules, for a resolution drawn by him calling upon the Postmaster general for a report whether the Postmaster at Baton rouge was a defaulter, and leaving out the call for the correspondence— Chinn said he had in his possession a Letter from the man himself—acknowledging that he was a defaulter and justly removed—and he said that he specially wanted the correspondence— M’Kay’s motion to suspend prevailed; many members supposing that the Resolution once introduced would be open to Chinn’s amendment; but to cut that off, M’Kay made a speech and moved the previous question.— Chinn asked him to accept the amendment calling for the correspondence, but he refused— Indignant at this base trickery Lewis Williams moved a reconsideration of the vote to suspend the rules; but it was too late— The daily practices in the house have degraded it into a meeting of Sharpers.— The morning hour was gone. The Orders of the day were of private business; but the Rules were suspended by a vote oftounder the new rule not requiring a majority of two thirds— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Linn Banks in the Chair— John White of Kentucky had the floor and occupied the whole day in a Speech against the sub-treasury-bill.— White is a man of fine talents and an able debater; but his manner was so vehement, and his articulation so rapid that it becomes altogether indistinct— He repeats the word, Sir, at least every fifth word, and his discourse is one continued stream without division into paragraphs or construction of Sentences— I listened to him about an hour, and then went into the Senate-chamber where I found Mr Webster speaking on the bankrupt Bill, followed by Silas Wright— The question upon the compulsive clause as it is called was taken and retained. Mr Clay had moved to strike it out— The Senate had already struck out the Section, which included the Banks within the operation of the Law. Hubbard now moved an indefinite postponement of the whole subject which started a debate of three hours when the motion was rejected by a vote of 16 to 28. I returned to the house at 1/2 past 5.— White closed before 7. Ramsey took the floor. Adjourned— Mary Cutts here this Evening.
6. V. Saturday.

I left off this day the handkerchief in which my right arm has been slung since the dislocation of my shoulder. My right hand had already been much disabled before this accident and I have no hope of recovering entirely from its effects— At the House the morning hour was consumed in taking yeas and nays upon a Report and Bill from the Committee on Mileage— The Committee have undertaken to retrench the allowance for mileage, which is 8 dollars for every 20 miles, and the effect of which is to give the members who reside at the greatest distance from this city, more than double the pay of those who live in its neighbourhood Besides this Thomas H. Benton a Senator from Missouri, the palm of democracy, economy and reform; author of the East room Letter, and detected once at Chapel hill, North-Carolina, with stolen bank bills stuffed in his cravat introduced a mode of computation of the distance to his residence at St. Louis, which nearly or quite doubled his allowance for mileage; and since that time all the distant members have followed his example— Thus at the special Session of 1837. the pay of each member for attendance was 344 dollars for 43 days. My allowance for mileage was and always has been 400 dollars for 1000 miles travel, and I received 744 dollars for the whole— At the same Session Archibald Yell of Arkansas received 2240—dollars— His allowance for travel was 4750 miles at 40 cents a mile— The Committee on Mileage propose now to measure the distances by the nearest mail conveyances, a very imperfect remedy for the evil, but which has roused in arms all the distant members— Attempts were made this morning to discharge the Committee, but they failed—the rules were suspended by yeas and nays 107 to 48 to receive their report and bill—an effort was made to pass it without discussion; but that was defeated; as was a motion to make it the order of the day for next Monday or Tuesday— I foresee that there will be great zeal for the passage of the bill in one quarter, and cunning and successful contrivance to defeat it on the other— Private business was again set aside— Dromgoole offered a Resolution that the House should hereafter meet at 10. A.M—but it failed— Committee of the whole house on the state of the Union, Linn Banks in the Chair— The Independent Treasury-Bill, and William S. Ramsey, the cadaverous Harrisburg mob manager, the Orator of the day— I expected he was to pour out a torrent of burning lava; but he was dull and heavy, doling out a chapter from M’Cullock upon political economy, on the history of the Banks of Venice, and Amsterdam and Hamburg and London; with details about the consumption of wheat in France and England, and parallel columns of the amount of banking capital and the price of wheat and flour and bread— At 1/2 past 2 came the recess— I went to the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, and read newspapers till 4. then returned to the house, where I found the Speaker in the Chair and about 40 members present rejecting a motion to adjourn— A call of the house was ordered and suspended— Adjourned by yeas and nays 46. to 42. I walked home between 5 and 6— Antoine was here this morning, and I offered to pay him one of my notes.
7. V. Sunday

A tempestuous night, with torrents of rain and very heavy thunder— The rain continued till noon of this day, and then gradually cleared up, cold— I rode to the capitol, and heard Mr Cookman from Revelations 22.4. “And there shall be no more curse”— He gave a brief and very summary account of this book of the apocalypse, written by the evangelist John—the beloved disciple— This part of the discourse might have been well enlarged by allusions to the peculiar character of this apostle, an ardent, enthusiastic, affectionate Spirit, indicating the causes of that preference of the heart—which Jesus bestowed upon him over all his other disciples. The general character of the book was noticed— Its avowedly prophetic character— Its wild and sublime imagery. Its obscure and mysterious language; its progressive and still progressing eccom? far very far yet from their final consummation; and its ever blessed promise of a day to come, when there shall be no more curse upon the Earth— He then actuated to the curse itself—as pronounced by God, in the 3d. chapter of Genesis v. 14–19. first upon the serpent—then upon the woman—then upon the man—and finally upon the Earth— He amplified by specific enumeration, many particulars of the curse upon the woman, the man and the earth—and after describing the aggravations of human misery in this present condition of the world, he pointed out in his text and in the whole purport of the book of Revelation the divine promise of redemption from the curse— He then argued that the cause of the curse was Sin— Disobedience to the Will of God— And the removal of the curse was the voluntary self-subjection of Christ to the penalty. The atonement of Christ is the commonplace of Calvinism always terminating in declamation, in words of indefinite meaning— So it does with every Calvinistic preacher whom I ever heard; and so it did with Mr Cookman— But his final appeal to his auditory was solemn and pathetic— After dinner at St. John’s Church Mr Hawley read the evening service for Whitsunday and preached from Zechariah 4.8. “Moreover the word of the Lord came unto me, saying— 9. The hands of Zerubbabel have laid the foundation of this house, his hands shall also finish it; and thou shalt know that the Lord of hosts hath sent me unto you. 10. For who hath despised the day of small things?” a copious text, and very inadequate commentary— The last 4 lines of the version of the Psalms of David in the prayer books before 1832. read thus

lg.l: Would he (God) his saving power employ
To break his People’s servile band,
Should loudly echo through the land.

div.p: In a general convention of the episcopal church at Philadelphia 29 October 1832 a revised book of Psalms selected from the Psalms of David was substituted for them to be read in the episcopal churches, and in that revisal, the above verse is in the 11th. Psalm is altered, to read thus

lg.l: O that from Sion he’d employ
His might and burst th’ oppressive band!
Should loudly echo through the land

div.p: the last two lines are the same. The debasement both of the thought and of the expression in the alteration of the first two lines, is the brand of Slavery upon the Episcopal Church, in these United States.
Evening with my wife, Mrs Smith and Mrs John, at Mr T. B. Johnson’s.
8. V. Monday

Mr Trist called on me this morning to ask the return of the great mass of papers which he had left with me relating to his affairs— I had read only a part of them and asked him to leave them with me a few days longer to which he consented— I looked over the Laws for the increase of the army since 1829. and as in the institution of all such enquiries I found only matter to search for more—and meanwhile my time slipped from under me— By the most assiduous employment of my hours from 5 when I rise to 11. when I attend the house it is with the utmost difficulty that I keep up my daily Diary. If I turn aside for enquiry upon any subject whatever—political or literary, the Diary falls in arrear— I rode this morning to the Capitol, and met at the entrance door, Mr Abbott Lawrence, now first able to come there, after a confinement by sickness of more than three Months— But he came only to take leave of the Hall and leaves the City with his family to-morrow Morning to return home. He gave me the key to the draw of the desk before his Seat— His brother Samuel was with him; and asked me when my Speech of the 9th. instt. would be published— I told him I hoped to finish it in the course of this week— He said they were anxious to have it at Boston, and would republish the whole in a pamphlet— This was the regular day for the receipt of Petitions, but at 5 minutes past 11. I found them in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Banks in the Chair and Ramsey drawing to the conclusion of his discourse— He finished between 12 and 1. as he begun, superlatively dull, and was followed by Theron R. Strong, from Palmyra Wayne County New-York, who took for his text the Resolutions of the Legislature of that State against the subtreasury, and in commenting upon them assigned his reasons for the determination to support and vote for that Bill. They were venomous, sophistical and disingenuous like nine tenths of the reasonings of the mock democracy— He recognized the right of instruction from the constituent to the representative, and the duty of the representative on receiving instructions from his constituents to obey them or to resign—but he maintained that the Resolutions of the Legislature of New-York were not instructions—that the Legislature themselves did not speak the Sentiments of the people of New York— That the People of New-York would soon shew their real opinions to be directly the reverse of those of their present Legislature, and that next November would display the triumph of Van Buren, and democracy—and down he dropped into his seat— Then rose Albert G. Marchand of Greensburg, Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania, a squat little jew-faced rotundity, said to be the youngest member of the House, not more than 28, and the first thing that I heard of his Oration, was a reference to a Letter from Pliny to Trajan about Corporations— He was afterwards abundant in classical lore—and in the history of the ecclesiastical establishments of the middle ages in England— This lasted till the recess when I returned to the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, and received a Letter from my Son, which I answered— After the recess Marchand finished and Underwood began a counter speech— Committee rose, and house adjourned before 7. Walk home— Antoine here this Evening.
9. V. Tuesday

Antoine was here this morning, and I paid him by a check on the Bank of Washington my Note of 6 May 1835 for 1000 dollars. At the House I found them taking the yeas and nays, upon an amendment proposed by the Committee of Foreign Affairs to a joint resolution from the Senate, authorising the President of the United States to accept certain presents sent by the Imaum of Muscat to this Country—and a Lion and Lioness from the Emperor of Morocco—and directing that they should be sold, and the proceeds thereof placed in the Treasury.— The amendment was that the proceeds should be distributed equally between two charitable institutions in this City— The Amendment was adopted by yeas and nays 97 to 65— The previous question had already been ordered, and the Speaker was already putting the main question of engrossment when I rose and enquired whether Congress had ever authorised the acceptance of presents from foreign powers— The Speaker answered that he did not know; but the previous question had been ordered and there could be no debate— I persisted in the enquiry— The Clerk produced the joint Resolution of 13. Feby 1835. for disposing of a Lion and two horses received by the Consul of the United States at Tanjier from the Emperor of Morocco— I then affirmed that Congress never had in any one instance authorised the acceptance of presents, and asked the house to hear me but 5 minutes against the Resolution— Pickens sent the Constitution to the Clerk to read the prohibitions of the acceptance of presents, without the consent of Congress—and he said in his clashing tone of contemptuous ignorance that there was nothing in my objection—it was all imaginary— Cooper of Georgia moved to lay the whole subject on the table—withdrew his motion and then renewed it— Several voices asked that I might be heard; but Turney objected— Cooper’s motion was rejected by yeas and nays 55 to 111— Hoffman moved to recommit the Resolution to the Committee of Foreign Affairs by general consent; Pickens objected but finally consented upon condition that it should come up again to-morrow morning— I asked Cushing that the Committee should consider the case of Thomas Pinckney in 1798. After this flurry, and an abortive motion of Cushing to suspend the rules for the reception of reports of Committees, the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union upon the sub-treasury Bill, Linn Banks in the Chair— Underwood resumed and concluded his speech; a very good one against the Bill— He was followed by William Lucas of Charlestown, Jefferson County Virginia in favour of the Bill— A proser— I went into the Senate chamber where Hubbard was holding forth against the Bill for the relief of Fulton’s heirs— At the recess I came home and did not return— After dinner, dictated to Mary, for my speech of the 9th. Evening visits from Major Hook aged 81. And from Mr and Mrs Larned—and Mrs Newman, Mrs Larned’s mother.
10 IV:45 Wednesday

Judge Cranch was here this morning, and said he came to converse with me, and to ascertain whether any thing could be done to obtain the release of my nephew William S. Smith, from prison where he has been upwards of 14 months confined— I freely told the judge the reasons which have prescribed and yet prescribe to me my duty with regard to this case— The judge said that unless there should be some further process by the District Attorney, after next November he might be discharged by an order of the Court—and that the only other alternative was an application to the President of the United States—with this, I said I could of course have nothing to do.— I had notified as many members as I could find, of the select Committee appointed on the 5th. of February last, on the Letter from the Secretary of War, and the Memorial of the American Philosophical Society, asking an appropriation for the purpose of making magnetic and meteorological observations, to meet this morning at 10. in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures— The members of the Committee are Adams, Naylor, Davee, Sumter, Wise, Granger, Dawson, Duncan and Montgomery— Only four attended this morning.— Adams, Davee, Naylor and Wise— No Quorum being present nothing could be done.—Davee and Naylor were perfectly well disposed to the object, but Wise, thought the proposal might be made an excellent handle for ridicule at the stump, and thought Poinsett had shifted the responsibility of the proposition from himself upon me— He said he should propose a Letter of enquiry to Poinsett to know whether he recommended this measure, and said he could throughout all Virginia drive off any Loco foco Candidate from the field on this mere proposition.— I notified another Meeting of the Committee for next Monday morning at 10.— In the House, Curtis finished a very good and earnest speech on the motion to recommit the New-York Pilot Bill, as it is called and Hillen of Baltimore began his Speech in support of the repealing Bill— The facts are that until the year 1837. a small number of Pilots in the City of New-York had the monopoly of all the business of their profession in that port: and they had consequently become so neglectful of their duties that it had become a proverbial saying among mariners that a man was as lazy as a New-York Pilot— In March 1837. an act of Congress took away their monopoly; and since that time they have been diligent and vigilant upon compulsion; and are now clamorous for the repeal of the Law.— This Bill from the minority of the Committee of Commerce is a electioneering partizan measure to gratify and secure them— At the expiration of the hour the subtreasury Bill came up in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Banks in the Chair— Lucas had finished his Speech last Evening, and Marvin followed him against the Bill— At the recess I came home, and dictated to Mary After dinner without coming to a close.
11. IV:45— Thursday

Mr Trist called here again this morning, and I returned to him a part of his papers which I had read.— A young man by the name of Perry from Abington, Massachusetts, and a teacher in the Navy—attached to the Razee Independence was here yesterday and again this morning— He told me that he had written me a Letter a Month or six weeks since; but I have no recollection of having received it, and cannot find it upon my files— He complains of some recent regulation of the Navy Commissioners, in assigning the station of the Teachers in our public ships among the midshipmen, whom they are to instruct— I advised him to see and converse with Mr John Reed, a member of the Naval Committee— He said he was personally acquainted with Mr Reed and had seen him. I said I thought his complaint appeared to be reasonable— And if a remedy for it could be applied it must be through the naval Committee— And I would render any assistance to the purpose, in my power— I attended at the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, but there was no Quorum— The Members present besides myself were Tillinghast and Davis only. absent Dromgoole, Nisbett, Worthington, Eastman, Mitchell and Slade— There was besides a multitude of Memorials, a Bill from the Senate referred to the Committee—upon which without a Quorum no action could be had— In the House Solomon Hillen junr. consumed the morning hour in a plea of monopoly for the New-York Pilots, with an argument to prove that he was opposed to all monopolies— He did not finish— The mileage Bill was taken up— Black of Georgia moved to lay it on the table— Yeas and nays 26 to 130. Dromgoole called the yeas and nays and the bill was passed 148 to 13 Thompson of Mississippi moved a reconsideration— The Bill will cut off about 800. dollars of his allowance for travel at each Session. He said it was a struggle between the two parties in the house to out-demagogue each other. However true this might be it did not help his cause— Underwood called the Previous question, and the vote for reconsideration was lost—29. to 135.— Petrikin objected to the Bill from the Library Committee concerning international exchanges, and it was referred to the Committee of the whole House— The sub-treasury Bill was now again taken up, in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Banks in the Chair, and Isaac Parish of Cambridge Ohio, who had taken the floor yesterday just before the recess, and consumed all the afternoon sitting in support of the Bill, wasted alike the remainder of the morning till the recess, without concluding. I came home, calling on my way at the Office of the National Intelligencer to inform Mr Gales that I expected to have my Speech of the 9th ready for publication to-morrow.— He said it should be published next Monday— I did not return to the House but dictated to Mary, drawing towards the conclusion of my speech— No small part of this day was engaged in hunting up documents respecting the acceptance of presents by Officers of the United States from foreign powers.
12. IV:45. Friday.

Hillen of Baltimore occupied three fourths of the morning hour in concluding his Speech for the repeal of the Pilot Law; and Moses Grinnell a member from the City of New-York, and a merchant commenced a reply— This was a day devoted by the rules of the house to private business—but the rules were suspended by a bare majority vote—for the subtreasury— Botts of Virginia threw into the house a hand-grenade, which exploded to the great alarm of the Slavers— Sometime last winter, a Lieutenant in the Navy named Hooe, a Virginian was tried by a Court martial at Pensacola; and two black men, the Steward and Cook of the vessel were admitted by the Court as witnesses against him— He protested against their admission; but he was convicted of the offence charged against him and sentenced to some partial suspension from the service— The Secretary of the Navy Paulding confirmed the sentence, and President Van-Buren endorsed upon the proceedings that he saw no reason for his interference in the case— Botts asked leave to introduce a Resolution, calling for copies of the proceedings on this Court-Martial, with a preamble of bitter censure upon the Court for admitting the testimony of the two Negroes. Botts came to my seat before he offered the Resolution, and asked if I should object to it— I said certainly not as a call for papers— But I said I should not view the transaction in the same light that he did— He said nothing to me of his preamble— Objection was made to his Resolution—he moved a suspension of the Rules— He carried a majority to suspend but not two thirds. 95 toThe servile phalanx was broken— All the whigs North and South voted to suspend— Stragglers, north and Semi-South deserted from the Kinderhoek ranks— Pickens swore like uncle Toby’s armies in Flanders, and bolted to dodge the vote— Frank Thomas Snake number one, could not think of admitting such a Resolution, without time to reflect— M’Kay, snake number two voted against suspending, and then offered himself a Resolution calling for the papers without preamble— But the house would not receive it—and he gave notice that he would offer it again to-morrow— The rules for the consideration of private business were then suspended.— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Banks in the Chair— Daniel D. Barnard took the floor and spoke till the recess without concluding, against the Bill— He spoke as usual admirably well: but he spoke to the stone pillars— The debate is so hacknied that the voice of one from the dead could not rouse attention to it.— I came home, and did not return to the house after dinner; but dictated to Mary the conclusion of my speech of Saturday the 9th. of May. I read also a part of the voluminous papers left with me by Mr Trist— Particularly his Report to the Secretary of his controversy with Captain Abraham Wendell jr Master of the Brig Kremlin of New-York, at the Havana— He makes a very strong case against Wendell.— Dr Hall and Dr Lindsley were here this Evening to make enquiries respecting the Smithsonian fund— Poor encouragement.
13. IV:45 Saturday

Mr Trist, called again this morning for his papers; and I returned to him all those that I had at my house—though I had not been able to read more than half of them— He said he wished to make out from them a summary statement of the case with the additional evidence of the Spanish proceedings of the Court at the Havana, by whose decree Captain Wendell had been imprisoned.— At the House I found Mr Grinnell concluding his speech against the repealing pilot-bill— After him Joel Holleman, of Burwell Bay, Isle of Wight, Virginia, took the floor, for the repeal, in behalf of the Virginia Pilots who sympathise with the monopolizing interest of those of New-York— The previous question had been moved, but was withdrawn— Holleman had spoken only a few minutes when the morning hour expired and Jones, chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, moved a suspension of the rules (private business) to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, upon the sub-treasury Bill— Wise, in behalf of Botts who was engaged with the Committee of Elections, moved a suspension of the rules for the naked Resolution, without the preamble that he had offered yesterday, calling on the Secretary of the Navy for copies of all the proceedings, of the trial by Court Martial of Lieutenant George M. Hooe of the Navy. But the rules were not suspended for there was now no opposition to the call— It was received and adopted by a general consent— The flutter of yesterday had all subsided, and the political capital against Mr Van-Buren furnished by this incident will be reserved for the stump.— Mr Banks was then called to the Chair of the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union and Charles Shepard of Newbern North-Carolina made a speech of an hour and a quarter in support of the Independent Treasury.— He is a deserter from the whig to the Kinderhoek ranks: frightened off by the bugbear of abolition. His old whig principles still linger loosely upon him; and his Speech was a sort of Salmagundi half whig, half-democrat.— He was followed by John Edwards of Ivy Mills, Delaware County Pennsylvania, in a cool, rational, but earnest speech of half an hour against the Bill— He finished at quarter past 2. He sat down; and no one rose to take the floor—a pause of two or three minutes ensued and then a call for the question, which was on a motion to strike out the enacting clause—but there was no quorum to vote. E. Davies moved the Committee to rise—refused 20 to 40. but the Committee rose and the Chairman reported no Quorum— Morgan moved to adjourn— Dromgoole called the yeas and nays 35 to 50. and while they were taken the time for the recess arrived— Mr Saltonstall rode home with me— I did not return to the House after dinner.— The day was of intense Summer heat, as yesterday had been Fahrenheit at 90. After two hours of Giusta I devoted the remaining day light to the revisal of my speech of the 9th. Mrs Thornton, Mrs Talbot with her daughter, and Richard and Mary Cutts were here this evening
14. IV:30— Trinity Sunday

The wind came round last Evening to the North west and cooled the atmosphere and this was a pleasant and beautiful day. I took the manuscript Report of my Speech of 9. May to the Office of the National Intelligencer, and left it with Mr Gales. In the Hall of the house of Representatives, I heard Dr Bates’s discourse upon intellectual education; being a sequel to the Sermon which I had heard him deliver, this day fortnight— His text now was Proverbs 8.10. [“]Receive my instruction, and not silver; and knowledge rather than choice gold.” The Doctor’s views of intellectual education, were chiefly confined to boys, and to the process of schooling and of collegiate discipline— He surveyed the various sources of influence to be used in stimulating youth to diligent study— Filial duty—curiosity—the love of praise—ambition—but not emulation—no competition—no prizes. No placing of one boy above another for better spelling— Nothing in which the gratification of one boys pride consists of another’s humiliation.— The Doctors opinions are practical, judicious, and benevolent, but the seats of the members were not half-filled with auditors; and the number of members of Congress present did not exceed 25. Yet the Doctor had given repeated notice in the Newspapers of his intention to preach the Sermons, and specially invited their attendance— But three fourths at least of the members of Congress never attend public worship in this City, any where— Miss Cutts dined with us, and at 4. P.M went with me and Mary-Louisa to the Presbyterian Church in 4 1/2 Street, where we heard, the Revd. E. N. Kirk an itinerant preacher highly renowned for eloquence— The house was full; but not overflowing— Mr Kirk is a young very good looking man, and an Orator better suited to a methodist camp meeting, than to a presbyterian Church— His text was the whole 26th. chapter of the Book of Acts. and especially the 28th. verse “Then Agrippa said unto Paul, Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian”— Mr Kirk told his hearers that a large portion of them were in the precise condition of Agrippa, almost Christians, and then he rung the changes upon almost Christians till I thought him almost an impostor— His manner of delivery is lively and deeply interesting—his language good—his imagery brilliant and impressive his earnestness much too agonizing—and his doctrines the most hacknied commonplance of Calvinism—the yawning precipice; the blood of Calvary, and the hottest of hell-fires— Much of his discourse was in the form of familiar dialogues between himself and his almost Christian hearers in which personating both parties he gave himself the victory, and sent his interlocutor without boil or main prize to Hell— I took a short walk with my wife early this Evening— There was fire, by which Mrs Goodes daughter Mary Mitchell and her husband were burnt out of their house and home in the compass of half an hour— The child was brought here and Jane came with it.
15. IV:45. Monday.

Dr Thomas was here this day while I was at the house, and left some oiled silk to paste over my shoulder and arm, which are yet weak and sore, and of which I shall probably never more have the perfect or even vigorous use; but which might henceforth furnish me the occasion to exercise the virtues of fortitude and resignation if I possessed them— I had nearly forgotten my own call of a meeting at 10 this morning of the select Committee on the Memorial of the American Philosophical Society at Philadelphia praying the aid of the Government for the establishment of stations of Magnetical and meteorological observations in concert with those instituted by the British and other European governments— I reached the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures at a quarter past 10—but only three other members of the Committee attended—Wise, Naylor and Montgomery.— Of the other members, Granger has gone home sick— Duncan, Sumter, Dawson and Davee had been notified by me, but did not attend— There was no quorum; but Mr Wise offered his resolution calling upon the Secretary of War, Poinsett, for his opinion, upon the application of the Society.— I made a few observations to oppose it—and Mr Montgomery said he was ready to vote for the appropriation— We adjourned to meet again on Wednesday morning— At the House, immediately after the reading of the Journal, Jones moved to suspend the rules (Resolution day) to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Wise asked his permission to offer a joint resolution for fixing the day of adjournment on the 11th. of July, but he declined— The Rules were suspended. Mr Banks took the chair of the Committee, and Mr John Pope of Kentucky had the floor He was not in the house and Mr Black of Georgia proposed to take his place—but while it was in discussion whether this could be allowed Mr. Pope came in, and commenced a random rambling Speech against the sub-treasury Bill which continued until the recess— He said the Speech was made for his constituents and not for the house— I could not stand it, and found other occupation, in commencing a poetical address in Ottava-rima, to the Marble Statue of Clio over the Clock at the front entrance of the Hall I went also into the Senate chamber and obtained from Mr Silas Wright, a copy of the amended Bill reported by the Senate’s committee of finance from the bill passed in the house for the more perfect collection of the revenue— They have superadded to it an entire Bill of 13. Sections; and have considerably extended the 9th Section which I had such extreme difficulty in carrying through the house— I came home and dined, and my wife and Mary-Louisa rode with me to the Capitol, after dinner. Stop’d on my way at the Office of the National Intelligencer and received the proof slips of my speech of 9. May, which I revised at the house and sent back to the Office— Mr Pope closed his speech at a quarter past 5. and was followed by a fiery speech of Black against Gamble, now a candidate in Georgia against him for election to the next Congress— At 7 the Committee rose, the house adjourned, and I walked home—
16. IV:30. Tuesday

My Speech on the 9th of May, furnishes four columns to the National Intelligencer of this morning. But a spirit of indolence is coming over me; and I am tasking my brain too much for Stanzas to Clio— I called this morning at the Franklin Insurance Office to receive my dividend and when I reached the house, they were taking the yeas and nays on a motion of William K. Bond, Chairman of a select Committee on a memorial of William Wright, for an enquiry into the settlement of Accounts between the United States, and the Commonwealth’s Bank at Boston, to suspend the rules to allow him to make a report from the Committee—but the house refused to suspend 55 to 84— The previous question had been ordered on the Bill to repeal the pilot law of 2. March 1837— The motion to recommit was of course set aside and the Bill passed to a second reading 93 to 89. At the second reading there was as usual much dirty trickery to snatch the floor from Tillinghast who had risen to speak against the repeal; but the Speaker persisted in giving him the floor and he made his Speech—not a long one— He was followed by George W. Toland of Philadelphia; also against the repeal; who was soon interrupted by the expiration of the morning hour, and the demand of Charles Fisher of North-Carolina, a member of the Committee of Elections to be discharged from farther Service on that Committee— His only alleged reason for which was that he had other indispensable business to attend to, which he could not do and serve further on that Committee— Debate arose— The whigs were all against excusing him— He finally intimated that he would no longer serve whether the House should excuse him or not— The vote by yeas and nays to excuse him was 105 to 97. the New-Jersey intruders all voting with the Majority— Vanderpoel voted against it. The rest was a close party vote I believe, and told Fisher that it was unwillingness to pass sentence upon his friends— This he faintly denied. I had some conversation with him upon the sub-treasury Bill, which I said would be a powerful engine in the hands of Mr Van Buren’s successor.— He said he had not the slightest doubt of Van-Buren’s re-election; but that he should vote against the sub-treasury. I told him I could hardly believe that; but he said I might— He may perhaps not vote for it.— When it came up this morning, Banks in the Chair, Black of Georgia emptied his bag of balderdash against his whig colleagues and especially against Gamble, his competitor for the next Congress— King and Nisbet occasionally interrupted him to explain but only quickened the crackling of his faggot fire— John W. Crockett followed him against the Bill till the recess. I came home and slept about two hours after dinner— Two of the work men employed on the Treasury building brought me a memorial which they requested me to present to the House praying an appropriation for the further extension of that building—which I promised to do—if I could— I went to the Capitol about 7. O’Clock, and found Mr Bell speaking against the sub-treasury bill— He had succeeded Crockett— A few minutes after I reached the House the Committee rose, and the house adjourned 55 to 55 by the casting vote of the Speaker.
17. IV:30 Wednesday.

Dr Thomas was here this morning, and looked at my shoulder and arm which are yet weak and sore; and much disabled, so that I can neither dress nor undress myself. They are now rubbed morning and evening with a liniment, and covered with strips of oiled silk— I had called again a meeting of the select Committee on the Memorial of the American Philosophical Society at ten this morning. Wise, Naylor and Montgomery were again there— Absent Duncan Dawson, Davee and Sumter— After waiting till about a quarter before 11. The members present became impatient and adjourned to Saturday— Ten minutes after Dr Duncan came to me in the house, and said he had been waiting half an hour in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures— As soon as the Journal had been read, I started with half a dozen others—“Mr Speaker”— The Speaker gave the floor to Petrikin who moved to suspend the rules for a Resolution to adjourn on Thursday the 9th of July at 8 O’Clock in the Evening— Yeas 77 Nays 88. Rules not suspended— “Mr Speaker” again— He now gave the floor to Craig of Virginia, who moved a suspension of the rules for a Resolution that from and after this day the hour of meeting of the house should be 10 O’Clock A.M— This time the rules were suspended yeas 150. nays 30 previous question carried—and the Resolution adopted— “Mr Speaker”—tertio. Edwards of Pennsylvania got the floor and moved a suspension of the rules for a Resolution directing the Clerk to cause the names of all the members of Congress, absent at any call of the house or taking of yeas and nays—to be published in one or more of the city Newspapers— Yeas 106. nays 70. not two thirds— Rules not suspended— “Mr Speaker[”]— This was my fourth call—made while he was saying Reports from Committees are in order.— He now heard me and gave the floor.— I asked leave in a very low voice to present a short memorial from John M Taggart Andrew Hough and 133 workmen on the Treasury building—to be referred to the Committee on the public buildings— The objectors did not hear me.— The memorial was received and referred Curtis from the Committee of Commerce reported two or three Bills.— Petrikin and Vanderpoel objected immediately to the consideration of one of them which was postponed for a week and the morning hour expired— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Banks in the Chair— Bell continued his speech against the Independent Treasury Bill till the recess— I passed that in chamber of the Committee of manufactures, reading Newspapers— After the recess Bell resumed his Speech, and spoke till 7. without approaching to a close. The Committee then rose forward of a quorum but a motion to adjourn failed with a quorum. I left the house, took up Mr Vattemare at his lodgings—and brought him home with me, and he entertained all our company till past Midnight, with seven Porté Folio’s of Paintings and drawings and other curiosities—and wondrous arts of ventriloquism.
18. V. Thursday.

Professor Meiere came to make enquiries respecting the house, next to Captain Carbery’s, which I gave to my wife some years since, and which Mr Frye has leased for five years to a german mechanic on condition of his making upon it, certain annual repairs.— Mr Meiere wishes to purchase of this German, his lease, and he is willing to sell it; but he has admitted into the house as Co-tenants, a worthless man, and his wife no better, but a fortune-teller; and knew not how to get rid of them— Mr Meiere expressed great surprize, that in this enlightened age, there should be persons earning their living by fortune-telling—but said that Captain Carbery had assured him that the Carriages of many of the most respectable families in this City and in Georgetown, had been seen standing at the door of that house, and Ladies alighting from them to have their fortunes told— I referred Mr. Meiere to Mr Frye, for any information or arrangement concerning this matter: the property being left wholly to his disposal as my agent— I went to the House at 9 this morning and about a quarter before 10. we had a quorum of the Committee of Manufactures—Adams, Eastman, Tillinghast, Mitchell, Dromgoole and Davis— Absent Slade, Nisbet and Worthington— The Bill from the Senate N. 218 for regulating the duties on Statuary and Paintings was taken up. I proposed to report against its passage, as a Bill to raise revenue, which by the Constitution could not originate in the Senate— All the members of the Committee present concurred in this opinion, but there was discussion upon the form of the report which I was directed to prepare in writing and then notify another Meeting of the Committee— In the House immediately after the reading of the Journal, Edward Curtis of New-York announced in a very feeling and eloquent address, the decease of his Colleague Anson Brown, at his own home, last Sunday evening. Curtis moved the usual resolutions, and the house immediately adjourned— I prevailed upon Naylor, Montgomery, Dawson and Davee to meet in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, on the Memorial from the American Philosophical Society— We had a quorum; but Wise, Granger, Sumter and Duncan were absent, and Dawson, took side, for Wise’s proposed Resolution to call on the Secretary of War Poinsett for his opinion of the expediency of the appropriation— Naylor, Montgomery and Davee were ready for an appropriation of 20000 dollars— No conclusion— Mr Pickens was in the adjoining chamber of the Committee of Foreign Affairs and drew me into a conversation of more than two hours, which he will misuse in making up his report upon the negro captives of the Amistad and for his argument on the acceptance of presents— I was not wise—mais que voulez vous? when am I wise? I visited Lieutenant Gilliss at his observatory— He shewed me his magnetic and astronomical instruments—for observing the variation the dip and the intensity— His Transit instrument, repeating Circle, and Azimuth compass. I shall visit him again— Walk home. Evening visit to my neighbour Albion K. Parris— Virgil D. Parris was there.
19. IV.30. Friday

After a good Night’s rest this was the first day since my disaster—that the pain in my shoulder and arm is sensibly diminished— It has constantly been affected by the state of the atmosphere— Yesterday was a sultry day, and my walk home from the Capitol hill, under the burning Sun without an Umbrella, was a heedless experiment— There was a heavy thunder shower in the evening, after which it cleared away, cool almost to a frost, and followed by a bright sky and bracing air, all this day— At five minutes past ten I entered the house, and found them in a bustle upon an Alabama squatters pre-emption Bill, which the members from Alabama, were struggling to drive through without sending it to a Committee of the whole— There was a remnant of reluctance upon the most submissive of the party Slaves— Cost Johnson denounced in the most abominable frauds of the Alabama Land sales— A motion was made to lay the Bill on the table— The Alabama members called for the yeas and nays and could not obtain them, for tellers and could not get them— A vote of a large majority laid the Bill on the table— But Graves of Kentucky hearing around him some whisper of a motion to reconsider moved it himself and the previous question— The party tocsin was in the sound of Graves’s voice— The Alabama members called again for the yeas and nays and they not only obtained them, but the vote just taken was reconsideredtoand then the Bill was referred to the Committee of the whole and made the order of the day for to-morrow— Two or three other Reports from Committees were received till the expiration of the hour when at the motion of J. W. Jones the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Linn Banks in the Chair, and George Evans made a powerful Speech of three hours against the Independent Treasury Bill; closing prematurely at the recess, leaving several topics which he had intended to treat untouched— When he sat down Joseph L. Tillinghast took the floor on the same side—and after the recess discoursed till Sunset when I left him speaking, without indicating any approach to a close— I then left the house and walked home, meeting on my way several members of the democracy returning to the house; one of whom Steenrod I heard say that they intended to sit it out to Night and get the Bill out of Committee— During the recess of the house I went into the Senate chamber and found Mr White of Indiana descanting upon I could not discover what— Mr John Davis promised that he would give his attention to the Bill for the relief of Ebenezer Lobdell. Mr Henry Clay told me that he had read my Speech on the Evidence question, and concurred entirely with my principles. I went to the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures and commenced a report upon the Memorial of the American Philosophical Society—but I had not written half a page, when the hour of four came and I returned to the Hall— The Report ought to be at once a scientific and a political state paper but I am not capable of writing it.
20. IV:30 Saturday

Soon after 9 this morning I attended at the chamber of the Committee of Manufacturers for a Meeting of the select Committee on the Memorial from the American Philosophical Society; but found only Mr Naylor there— Engaged in a conversation with him till on repairing to the Hall we found the house in Session and receiving Reports from Committees— At the expiration of the hour, the rules of private business were suspended; the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Linn Banks in the chair—and Walter T. Colquitt of Georgia made a Speech of 3 hours in favour of the Bill, and against the Bank of the United States and all Banks.— Colquitt is a ranting methodist preacher; a middle sized man, of swarthy complexion, and crispy curls between hair and wool, raising ominous conjecture of an infusion of African blood in his animal mechanism— Low in stature, with eyes black as jet and Ladino platitude of face. His articulation is so rapid and indistinct—his gesticulation so violent and contortive, that he looks more like a stage-tumbler making somersets than like a decent pulpit preacher— I could not hear a twentieth part of what he said, and what I did hear was not worth hearing— He is one of the three Georgian Apostates from the party which elected him, and has with the other two, Black and Mark A. Cooper, been dropped from the whig ticket for the next Congress— He was followed by Robert Barnwell Rhett a South-Carolina nullifier of the absurdest stamp a compound of wild democracy and iron bound slavery combined with the feudal cramp of State Sovereignty. The mongrel brood of doctrinal nullification— Rhett spoke till the recess, and resumed on the return of half a Quorum to the house—he finished about 5—there was for the second time a pause—a motion to rise and report the Bill; but there was a pending motion to strike out the enacting clause, and no quorum to take the question— David D. Wagener of Easton, Northampton County Pennsylvania, then rose and read a speech of about half an hour for the Bill, and against the Banks— Wagener is a quiet, peaceable Pennsylvania democrat who would be an honest man if he could— Mark A. Cooper then took the floor and moved the Committee to rise— They rose for want of a Quorum and the house adjourned by yeas and nays 45 to 44— During the recess, and for an hour and a half after the adjournment I was in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures working at a report on the Memorial from the American philosophical Society—a desperate labour. I then went down and found in the Eastern yard the Musical Band of the Marine Corps serenading the public, with a cluster of Carriages in the Yard, and a gathering of people on the flight of steps and Portico— The Music continued till the splendid Sunset of a beautiful day— I walked round the eastern garden and then home— Found Mr Frye here, and he spent the evening with me in conversation on my private business
21. IV:30. Sunday

My wife and Mary Cutts accompanied me this morning to the Capitol, where we heard Mr Cookman preach from Romans 8.2. “For the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus hath made me free from the law of sin and death.”— How much benefit I ever have derived from hearing the gospel preached I am unable to estimate, but Mr Cookman posesses a power of reason and of persuasion over my judgment, feelings and Memory, not inferior to that of any man whom I ever heard. By the Spirit of Life in Christ Jesus Mr Cookman understands eternal life, and resurrection from the dead— The great and vital article of Christian Faith— “I am the resurrection and the life.” Mr Cookman’s exhortations are tender and affectionate— He dwells upon the tender mercies of God— He calls the sinner to repentance by arguments implying that the hearer’s will is under his own controul— He made some very forcible remarks upon a doctrine very current among free-thinkers; that a man cannot be accountable for his faith or belief; which he said one of the master Spirits of the age had pronounced altogether involuntary and independent of the Will— He replied that man was accountable at least accountable for attention—for hearing—and quoted St. Paul, that Faith comes by hearing, and hearing by the word of God— I glanced at this topic last October at Braintree, and wish I could examine it thoroughly. The Hall was well filled with hearers, but not many in the galleries—less than 30 members of Congress— Miss Cutts dined with us. Mrs John and her daughter Mary-Louisa went Friday Morning on a visit to Mrs Frye—to return to-morrow— As we rose from dinner I had a visit from Mr Benjamin Rush, eldest son of Richard Rush, and Secretary of the Legation of the United States at London. He has just arrived in the Steamer Great Western, after a passage of 14 1/2 days— He comes as a special bearer of despatches from our hopeful Minister at the Court of Queen Victoria, Andrew Stevenson— A Messenger to the British Minister here Mr Fox—came by the same vessel— They bring a proposition from the British Government relating to the Northeastern boundary question; not definitive, but approaching to it.— Mr Rush thinks the question will be amicably adjusted— He expects to depart about the 1st. of August to return to England.— At 5. P.M. I attended at St. John’s Church, where Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the first Sunday after Trinity, and preached a Sermon, not much longer than the text, from Isaiah 52.7— “How beautiful upon the mountains are the feet of him that bringeth good tidings, that publisheth peace; that bringeth good tidings of good, that publisheth salvation; that saith unto Zion, thy God reigneth.”— Watts’s admirable Hymn—[“]How beauteous are their feet”—is a paraphrase of this and the three succeeding verses, and I never read them with out a thrill of enthusiastic hope and admiration— I took a walk this Evening with my wife. We met Mr and Mrs Poinsett, and Mr and Mrs Gilpin.
22. IV:45. Monday—

I went to the Capitol at 9 this morning to finish if I might, the draught of a report upon the memorial from the American philosophical Society; but found Mr Tillinghast at the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, and whiled away the hour in conversation with him— At the house, Clifford moved a suspension of the rules for a Resolution with a preamble, to discharge the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, from and after next Friday from and after next Friday, from the further consideration of Senate Bill N. 127. (the Subtreasury) and that it be taken up in the house on Saturday at Noon; unless sooner reported, and then pursued till finally disposed of— Wise moved a Call of the house, which was ordered and executed till the closing of the doors when all further proceedings were suspended— The vote to suspend the rules was 109 to 76. not two thirds.— But the rules were immediately suspended to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Banks in the Chair on the Subtreasury Bill. James Cooper of Gettysburg Pennsylvania made a speech of two hours against the Bill, and was followed by Kenneth Rayner of Winston, North-Carolina, on the same side, who spoke till the recess, without concluding— Both these Speeches were spirited and highly eloquent—but Cooper was called to order and pronounced so by the Chairman for irrelevancy, because in a personal explanation he was refuting a lie about his election. I came home at the recess, and did not return to the house till about Sunset; when my wife and Mrs. John, taking their ride, dropped me at the Capitol, and after half an hour took me up again and we came home— Mr Saltonstall came with me at the recess.— Mr Morsell’s son, paid me at the Capitol this day, 100 dollars with 1:30 interest on it from 31. March last when it was payable—by his fathers contract with me for the sale of the house which had been Daniel Bakers. I took up the receipt for 100 dollars which I had given his father on the 31st. of March for the sum then paid, and gave him now a receipt for the 200.— I met in the lobby of the house this day Bishop Chase, now of the State of Illinois, and judge Alexander Porter of Louisiana— Judge William Cranch also put into my hands, a report made by him for a Committee of the late Columbian Institute, upon a proposal made by the Secretary of War Poinsett, that the relics of the Columbian Institute should merge themselves or be merged in the new National Institution for the promotion of Science— The report warmly recommends the acceptance of this offer— The Charter of the Columbian Institute expired in May 1838. and there has not been in the body itself, nor in the heads of Departments who were members of it interest enough in the pursuits to which it was devoted, to procure, or even so much as to apply for the continuance of its Charter— I was myself a member and at one time President of that Society.
23. IV:30. Tuesday.

Mr Radcliff of New-York called on me this morning, still dreaming of a ship-canal, or railway across the Isthmus of Panama.— He told me he was going to Europe; and enquired if I thought there would be any impropriety in his applying to the Government of Holland to accomplish this object. I said none at all. But that I thought the king of Holland too old to engage anew in a project which twelve years ago he had undertaken with out success. I left at Mr Vattemare’s one of Fursts silver medals of 4. March 1825. with a Letter from my wife presenting it to him— I reached the house only a few minutes before ten. Wise moved a suspension of the rules to offer his resolution for adjourning on the 11th. of July at 2. P.M— Call of the house, till the close of the doors, and then further proceedings suspended— Vote on the suspension of the rules 75 to 94.— I presented to the house, in behalf of Daniel Raymond a copy of his book on political economy, and moved that it should be deposited in the library, which was ordered— Cushing came to my seat and said he had thought of opposing the reception of the book. I asked why? he said he thought it an improper mode of advertising the book. I said, well—make your motion—but he did not— I reported from the Committee of Manufactures against the passage of Senate Bill N. 218. to regulate the duties on Sculpture and paintings. the Resolution at the close of the Report to postpone the bill indefinitely on the presumption that it passed the Senate by inadvertence, was adopted without discussion or opposition— At the expiration of the morning hour, Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Linn Banks in the Chair; and the Subtreasury— In the half-hour that I was in the house last Evening, Holleman was all the time demonstrating that the Bank of the United States never furnished a currency or regulated exchanges. he spoke for about an hour after I left the house, and then they adjourned.— This Morning he resumed, and regularly went over the same demonstration again, till for very weariness I went into the Senate chamber, where they were discussing the Bankrupt Bill. Returning to the House I found Jenifer commencing a speech against the Bill, which was soon suspended by the recess. I went to the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures and wrote, to the severe exercise of my arm till 6. O’Clock.— Returning then again the house, I found them all in a hubbub. Jenifer had quoted an insolent closing paragraph of a Speech of Theron R. Strong, and said he would reply to it. Banks the Chairman called him to order, before he had begun to reply. Jenifer appealed; and Banks put the question on the appeal, as if Jenifer had begun to reply— Jenifer reduced his appeal to writing, and demanded that the question should be put in his own language— Banks persisted in refusing to receive Jenifer’s appeal, and in putting the question in his own way— Tellers. Ayes to sustain the Chair 68. Nays—none.— Don’t vote! not one— Committee rose and reported no Quorum— Twice repeated— The third time Banks received Jenifers appeal—the house sustained the Chairman— Motion to rise 55 to 55. Chairman votes against rising. J. W. Allen took the floor and I came home.
24. IV:30. Wednesday. St. John Baptist.

Mrs Angus, widow of Captain Samuel Angus, called on me this morning with her nephew to claim my assistance in obtaining a Pension for her. Captain Angus was Commander of the Sloop of War John Adams when in June 1814 I came in her from Gothenburg to the Texel— He had served with gallantry, and had been twice severely wounded in the head in that War in consequence of which his intellect was occasionally impaired— More than ten years afterwards he was dismissed from the service by sentence of a Court martial, for a grossly insulting Letter to the Secretary of the Navy, Southard— Great exertions wer afterwards made by his friends to obtain his restoration to the service; but that was found impracticable— The highest rate of pension however allowed by the Law, was secured to him— He died a few weeks since, and his widow now comes to claim the benefit of a pension for her support; for which I promised her any assistance that it may be in my power to bestow— At the house, Mr Botts, moved a suspension of the Rules to have read, the proceedings of the naval Court Martial upon the trial of Lieutenant Hooe; reported by the Secretary of the Navy, in answer to the call made some days since upon Botts’s motion— Jones of the ways and Means enquired if he proposed the suspension for the day or only for the morning hour— Botts agreed to confine it to the morning hour—and the rules were suspended by yeas and nays 145. to 25. my name being among the negatives— The papers were partly read: the first was a defence of excuse and apology of himself, sneaking enough—for having done his duty. Botts objected to this as a paper not included in the call— Before the reading was concluded the hour expired— Jones moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, but allowed Crabb to move a reconsideration of the vote of yesterday accepting the copy of Raymond’s book on political economy; with a view to have it referred to the Committee on the Library to examine and report upon it. Before I had an opportunity to understand Crabb’s motion, Turney moved the Previous question which was seconded and carried as by a whirlwind— I rose and asked leave to assign my reasons for presenting the book, but was told by the Speaker that the previous question had been ordered and there could be no debate— Crabb was in a furious passion at the chapter on Slavery that he had found in the book— The Speaker allowed him to vent his spleen, but the noise and confusion were so great that I could not hear what he said— Ramsey moved to lay the whole subject on the table— Crabb called for the yeas and nays, and then for tellers, in vain— The subject was laid on the table, by a vote of four or five to one— Crabb’s rage was now turned upon the Southern whigs and warm words passed between him and Stanley.— Committee of the whole on the Union— Banks in the Chair— Allen of Ohio finished, and Sergeant began a Speech— I came home at the recess— After dinner, Mary wrote for me— Evening at Mrs R. Johnson’s with Dr Sewall— Russell’s curious Planetarium—
25. IV:30 Thursday.

With Mary’s assistance, I finished yesterday afternoon the draught of a report upon the Memorial of the American Philosophical Society, asking the aid of Government for the establishment of five Stations for observations of terrestrial magnetism and meteorology— I had used my hand so much in writing, particularly the day before yesterday that my shoulder and arm became quite painful. I have been obliged therefore yesterday and this day to ask Mary to write for me, which she has cheerfully done— Mrs Frye and her Son Thomas were here yesterday afternoon— It was his twentieth birth-day. The Captain Hoskins marked in yesterday’s margin was the Captain of the Great Western Steamer, and was introduce to me, by James Monroe, at my Seat in the House. His visit to Washington is one merely of curiosity and he told me, that on this day week he should depart from New-York on his fourteenth passage across the Atlantic, within two years and two months— This morning at 9. I attended at the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, for a Meeting of that Committee— But Tillinghast and Eastman were the only other members who attended— No Quorum— At the House, Briggs immediately after the reading of the Journal moved the suspension of the Rules to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, setting aside even the morning hour— This was to cut off the reading of the remainder of the proceedings of the Court Martial on the trial of Lieutenant Hooe—and the rules were suspended. M’Kay of North-Carolina made an attempt to introduce a resolution for the printing of the papers; but failed, entirely to his own satisfaction. He gave notice however that he should offer the same resolution again to-morrow— W. Cost Johnson was equally unsuccessful in calling for the Bill from the Senate to continue for two years longer the charters of the District Banks— The house went into Committee of the whole; Banks took the Chair and Sergeant concluded the speech against the sub-treasury bill which he had commenced yesterday morning— A masterly Speech—but so long and on a subject so trodden down into barrenness, that I found it impossible to give it undivided attention. I went into the Senate chamber where I heard closing speeches of B. Tappan, and W. Allen against the Bankrupt Bill; which nevertheless passed by a vote of 21 to 19.— Sergeant finished at 1/2 past 1. and John Hastings of Ohio, began reading a written speech, from loose-leaves, and in so low a tone of voice that not twenty persons of his own party, clustered round him, could hear him—the rest of the hall was deserted— I came home at the recess, and did not afterwards return to the house—where Hastings finished reading his Speech. W. Cost Johnson made one of four hours, and Andrews of Kentucky occupied one hour more— They adjourned after ten at Night— I had employed the afternoon in dictating seven Letters to sundry persons which were written for me by my daughter Mrs John Adams— The day was intensely warm and sultry.
26. IV:45. Friday.

Our man servant Jeremy Leary was seized with the bileous cholic between midnight and one this morning with great violence— Dr Thomas was twice here in the course of the day to visit him— He was partially relieved this afternoon and evening. I had notified a meeting at 9 this morning of the select Committee on the Memorial of the American Philosophical Society of Philadelphia, but two members only besides myself attended—Mr Naylor and Mr Davee— Wise, Dawson and Granger, are now all absent from the city. It is a desperate chance to get a Quorum of the Committee, and I concluded to give the Report to the members of the Committee separately to read, and thus obtain permission from the majority of the Committee to present the report— I accordingly gave the report to Mr Sumter and Dr Duncan to read and they consented that I should make the report— Naylor and Davee had done the same before, and Dr Montgomery without reading it— I gave it also to John W. Jones, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means to read, and shewed him the item of appropriation which I proposed to move as amendment to the army appropriation-bill when up for consideration.— He said he could move no additional appropriation without authority from his committee.— In the House, Clifford moved again a suspension of the rules for a Resolution to discharge the Committee of the whole after Monday next from the further consideration of the Sub-treasury Bill, to take it up, and pass upon it in the house; and this time he carried it, by a vote of 123 to 58. more than two-thirds— Sergeant moved a suspension of the rules to take up the bankrupt Bill, received from the Senate—merely to have it referred to the judiciary Committee, and printed—the vote was 88 to 88. rules not suspended— M’Kay again feebly renewed his movement to have the documents concerning the trial of Lieutenant Hooe printed, but failed again— The rules were however immediately suspended to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Banks in the Chair— M’Cartney, the successor of Charles F. Mercer, who had taken the floor last Evening made a sensible Speech against the Bill, and was followed by Richard Biddle who spoke till the recess without concluding— I came home to dine and did not return to the house, though greatly regretting that I could not hear the remnant of Biddle’s Speech— I class the whig Orators in the house Corwin, Sergeant, Barnard, Biddle, each of whom might claim the first place— Biddle is in bad health, and resigns at the close of this Session—I lost the afternoon in sleep to make up for the broken rest of last Night. This Evening, I attended a meeting of the new American Institution for the promotion of Science— The Secretary of War, Poinsett was there, presiding, and the Secretary of the Treasury Woodbury, as a member. The American Historical Society have accepted the proposal to be merged in this New Society— Some alteration was made of the Constitution— I proposed and urged the necessity of an application to Congress for an Act of incorporation. Returning home judge Cranch stop’d at my house and took his papers.
27. IV:30. Saturday.

I find it almost impossible to keep up my daily record, and to reach the Capitol before ten in the morning. The house sat last evening till past ten— Mr Biddle finished his Speech and was followed by W. Cost Johnson—and he by Landaff W. Andrews of Kentucky, with one rising of the Committee for want of a Quorum, one call of the House, and two or three abortive motions for adjournment. This morning there was another flurry, about the report from the Secretary of the Navy—with the documents relating to the trial of Lieutenant Hooe— John M.
